properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:57 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-07-08T20:34:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T17:57:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3748151322.2020
Area: Saint-Hyacinthe - Acton Vale area, Saint-Jean - Marieville area, Drummondville area, Granby - Waterloo area, Brome-Missisquoi area, Richmond area

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain this afternoon and possibly into early this evening. Boaters may be surprised by strong wind gusts over bodies of water. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-08T23:59:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T17:09:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0929768583.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected. Daytime high temperatures reaching the low thirties in degrees Celsius will begin today and will continue through the end of the week. Overnight low temperatures of near 18 degrees Celsius will provide little relief from the heat. Cooler temperatures with showers or thunderstorms are expected to arrive Friday afternoon or evening. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T07:55:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T15:56:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2997651252.2020
Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki, Fort Albany, Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat wave continues this week. A warm and humid air mass over Southern Quebec will persist over the next few days. The heat wave will continue north of Montreal. Temperatures will exceed the 30-degree mark during the day and will not fall below 18 degrees at night. Combined values of the temperature and the humidity will give a humidex value of 40. These conditions are likely to persist into Saturday. During times of high heat, your health and the health of your family and friends can deteriorate rapidly. The ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux du Québec, in cooperation with Environment and Climate Change Canada, recommends that you protect yourself from the effects of the heat by taking the following actions: Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water per day. As appropriate, follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; Avoid alcoholic beverages; Spend at least 2 hours a day in an air conditioned or cool place; Take at least one cool shower or bath per day, or cool your skin several times per day with wet towels; Limit physical activity; Wear light clothes. Be sure to: Never leave a child or a baby alone in a vehicle or a poorly ventilated room, even for a few minutes; Check on your loved ones, especially those who are vulnerable or living alone. If you have any questions regarding your health, call Info-Santé by dialing 8-1-1 or ask a health care provider. In case of emergency, call 9-1-1. For more information, visit the Government of Quebec's Portail santé mieux-être at www.sante.gouv.qc.ca. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T07:09:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T15:10:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1772118695.2020
Area: Gatineau
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather will continue through the rest of this week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected this week. Overnight lows near 20 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. Current forecast guidance indicates the hottest temperatures and highest humidex values will occur on Thursday. A slightly cooler airmass may move into the area this weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty and the conditions may persist for a few areas into Saturday. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T07:12:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T15:13:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3608454443.2020

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions will be favourable for the development of funnel clouds today. ### These types of funnel clouds are generated by weak rotation under rapidly growing clouds or weak thunderstorms. This weak rotation is normally not a danger near the ground. However, there is a chance that this rotation could intensify and become a weak landspout tornado. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T08:20:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T16:20:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1172926837.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event continues through the end of the week. Inland from the Great Lakes, daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius will accompany humidex values in the mid thirties through the next several days. Overnight low temperatures in the upper teens are also expected during this period. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather will continue through the rest of this week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 31 degrees Celsius, with humidex values near forty, are expected this week. Overnight lows near or in excess of 21 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. Current forecast guidance indicates the hottest temperatures and the highest humidex values will occur this afternoon. A slightly cooler airmass with showers may move into the area late Friday or this weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T07:15:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T15:16:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2582585269.2020
Area: Chatham-Kent - Rondeau Park, Windsor - Leamington - Essex County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event continues through the end of the week. Daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius with humidex values in the low to mid thirties are forecast over the next several days. Overnight low temperatures in the upper teens are also expected during this period. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T08:33:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T16:34:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1643263481.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather continues this week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected this week. Overnight lows near 20 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. A slightly cooler airmass may move into the area this weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty. A few areas towards eastern Ontario are likely to experience extreme heat and high humidex values on Saturday as well. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The oppressive heat wave continues A warm and humid air mass over Southern Quebec will continue over the next few days. Temperatures will exceed the 30-degree mark during the day and shouldn't drop below 20 degrees at night. The combined temperature and humidity values will produce humidex values of 40. These conditions are expected to persist through Saturday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A slow moving low pressure system will continue to bring moderate to heavy rain to areas from the Battlefords westwards to the Alberta border. Amounts will vary across the region with the highest accumulations closer to the Alberta border. A further 20 to 60 mm of rain is possible today. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. Potential rainfall rates: possibly in excess of 25 millimetres per hour. Potential wind gusts: possibly in excess of 90 km/h. Locations: Edmundston and Madawaska County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, and western Restigouche Countiy. Time span: This afternoon into this evening. Remarks: Conditions are favourable for thunderstorms approaching from the northwest this afternoon. Conditions may become severe late this afternoon into this evening. The highest threat is for strong wind gusts, followed by local heavy downpours. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T01:45:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-08T16:53:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2832688566.2020
Area: Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County
